title_review: Vinos, Tapas y Amigos..  De Divino Tinto al Cielo!
review_preview: We discovered Divino Tinto on our last visit to Madrid and this year it was at the top of our !MUST! return to restaurants in the city.We were delighted that David remembered us as he so warmly welcomed us like friends upon arrival.It...
review_full: We discovered Divino Tinto on our last visit to Madrid and this year it was at the top of our !MUST! return to restaurants in the city. We were delighted that David remembered us as he so warmly welcomed us like friends upon arrival. It felt as if we were visiting old friends, but friends that not only make the best Tapas in Madrid but also have the most wonderful selection of small producer wines as well. All the selections on the menu are generous and designed to share, and all made to order. David expertly describes every dish and its preparation, including the local sourcing of the ingredients.. even down to which town and farm! As before, we left the wine pairing to David as he is a master at choosing the perfect wine to accompany each dish and even remembered our preferences from our last visit. After all, we were among friends and not just dining out! We started our adventure with the best Scallop Ceviche we have ever tasted, the sweetness of the scallop perfectly balanced by the tart sauce. Crisp in texture and tasting of the ocean, truly magic upon the tongue!  We followed the a very tender and fresh veal carpaccio dressed with the signature house olive oil, made by a friend from single variety grapes and produced in one farm only. So good we were tempted to have it by the glass. Next we enjoyed our absolute favorite from last year, the Baby Habitas with Grilled Chipis. Truly a dish to enjoy again and again with the habitas meltingly soft and a perfect counterpoint to the sweet and crunchy grilled calamari.  We could not finish our Tapas feast without trying the Lingote de Cochinillo, a wonderful slow cooked pulled pork creation served with the in season boletus mushrooms and a confit of figs cooked in port.. ESTUPENDO!!! Torrijas con Helado, a chupito of Pedro Ximénez and expressos revived us for our ride back to Malasana. Make sure to reserve a table if you are having dinner as there are only a few and it is always full with the local crowd.

Overall a great experience and I will recommend to anyone going to Madrid in a group, couple or alone. Thank you!

title_review: Lucky find on a Sunday afternoon!
review_preview: We were walking thru the park and it was getting late for lunch (3pm) and none of the ‘cafeteria’ style restaurants in the park were capturing our attention so looked on Tripadvisor for something nearby and this grabbed the attention of both of us.  Although...
review_full: We were walking thru the park and it was getting late for lunch (3pm) and none of the ‘cafeteria’ style restaurants in the park were capturing our attention so looked on Tripadvisor for something nearby and this grabbed the attention of both of us. Although in the wrong direction for where we were going next, it looked worth a go. So glad we did. It was tiny but full of locals and no other tourists (always the best to my mind) and I could see why once they managed to squeeze us in despite no reservation. It remained packed and people constantly trying to get in throughout our time there.  Our waiter was a lovely, warm and engaging guy. He recommended a few things to us which looked and sounded great but sadly we were only there for a light lunch so didn’t go for them but if we came back, we would. We went with a couple of very simple things - patatas bravas and manchego cheese which were both perfect. We also tried a new dish (for us) which was mushrooms and crispy spinach cooked with raisins and Pedro Ximenez - outstanding and one of the best tapas dishes we have ever had.  Couple of small beers and a glass of wonderful Ribera Del Duero (always blows my mind that I get a glass like this for less than €3 vs what I get in London!) made this the perfect lunch! If we come back to Madrid, we will defo come back here - could not recommend it enough. So much buzz abut the place coupled with wonderful service and that food/drink!

title_review: Lovely food, lovely staff for a very reasonable price
review_preview: I was in Madrid for a long weekend, mainly because two German friends were visiting there for the first time and I was "tour guide". As it was a few years since I was last there, many of the restaurants that I liked in the...
review_full: I was in Madrid for a long weekend, mainly because two German friends were visiting there for the first time and I was "tour guide". As it was a few years since I was last there, many of the restaurants that I liked in the Cheuca area have closed, so went to Esplore as a result of good reviews on here. Went alone on a Thursday night and had: starter - the morcilla (Spanish black pudding which I love) on toast with goats' cheese - for me, a wonderful combination of flavours and textures; for main course I had the rice with prawns and asparagus - was expecting the usual of, in Spanish restaurants, white asparagus but was fresh green asparagus which was a wonderful compliment to the prawns and the tomato based sauce of the rice; and a glass of a great Albarinho wine. Only "criticism" is that the portions were too big for me, but I have come to expect that in most spanish restaurants. Food is modern Spanish, so "with a twist" on traditional foodstuffs and dishes I booked a table for me and my friends for the Saturday night and they too loved the food and great service. We had the rice dish between us and they too enjoyed it as much as I had done.

review_full: We arrived here early on a Friday morning for a light breakfast, and we were certainly not disappointed. The place was still empty (it was early, as I mentioned) and we were seated in the area in the back of the entrance. Be aware that this place is very small (smaller than it looks in the pictures) and especially in the entrance it will be difficult to find a table to sit. We were informed by the waitress that we couldn't order fried eggs and we should go for poached eggs, which were their specialty, which was OK with us. We had 2 espressos and the eggs benedict with bacon, which were very tasty. Perhaps a person who is looking for a savoury brunch will want some more options to be added in the menu, but overall, there are plenty of options (wraps, sandwiches, salads, avocado toast) for a light and healthy breakfast (and all of them very reasonably priced).

title_review: Off  the Centro but direct to the heart..
review_preview: We enjoyed a delightful evening at Divino Tinto! The wine list is superb and very reasonably priced. The tapas and platillos were outstanding, all beautifully presented and the preparation faultless, truly worthy of the finest restaurant entrees.. and all in this small and extremely local...
review_full: We enjoyed a delightful evening at Divino Tinto! The wine list is superb and very reasonably priced. The tapas and platillos were outstanding, all beautifully presented and the preparation faultless, truly worthy of the finest restaurant entrees.. and all in this small and extremely local wine bar near the Legazpi metro just a short ride from Madrid's centro. This is a very small and intimate venue and we were warmly greeted by David upon arrival who made us feel welcome and 'como en su casa' as he escorted us to our table. Make sure to book ahead as there only a few tables for dining and this wine bar is truly a local hangout and very busy at night, but not noisy. David tends bar, takes orders and serves the tapas all with amazing cheer and charm. We enjoyed our tapas with vermouth's to start and four wines, plus a dessert wine as suggested by David. All from small Spanish bodegas, all luscious and satisfying! We would have sampled more but we had an early train from Atocha the next morning. The tapas, the wines, the service, oh my! this was truly one of the best meals we have ever enjoyed in Madrid and we can't wait to return. Thank you so much David for such a delightful evening!!!

Do yourself a favour - order the tartare tomate - a stack of tomatoes, soft cheese and crispy ham - one of the best dishes I’ve ever had. The croquettes and huevos rotos (fried egg, ham and potatoes) were also first class - we couldn’t fault it. This is obviously a place in the know with locals, for a really good reason. Try it - you won’t be sorry. Staff were really friendly and helpful in squeezing us in without a reservation and in describing the food.

The compensation for the bad paella was a dessert. The dessert was brownie bits purchased from some factory - terrible. Given all of the choices of great food in Madrid this rates at the very bottom. Oh, and I was surprised there were so many English speaking tourists eating here. Perhaps a social media phenom. Do not waste your money eating here.

review_preview: This restaurant came as a recommendation. Walking into the restaurant we had high hopes because the decor and lighting made for a good first impression. I can’t say I felt the same way upon leaving this restaurant. Overall, the server was friendly and attentive, but...
review_full: This restaurant came as a recommendation. Walking into the restaurant we had high hopes because the decor and lighting made for a good first impression. I can’t say I felt the same way upon leaving this restaurant. Overall, the server was friendly and attentive, but the food was quite underwhelming. We decided to try the Paella to get a sense of a staple Spain dish, but this dish completely missed the mark. The Paella was not very flavorful and was too crunchy to actually savor (i.e., burnt). Maybe if we had purchased a more expensive dish the the quality would have been better, but for a dish as simple and staple as Paella, I expected a lot more. While I’ve seen a lot of positive reviews of this restaurant, nothing really stood out to us enough to recommend to someone. However, if you do decide to eat here, go with something besides the Paella.

title_review: Small and welcoming with excellent food
review_preview: We visited this restaurant on the strength of the previous reviews, having eaten at similarly sized Mama Gus (small and unpretentious) the previous evening, which we had really enjoyed. Taberna Gastromaquia turned out to be another excellent choice. One of the staff, possibly the owner,...
review_full: We visited this restaurant on the strength of the previous reviews, having eaten at similarly sized Mama Gus (small and unpretentious) the previous evening, which we had really enjoyed. Taberna Gastromaquia turned out to be another excellent choice. One of the staff, possibly the owner, spoke excellent English and explained the menu (there is no English menu) and gave us recommendations. All the food was very good, particularly the goats cheese and the octopus, which was a real revelation. We got there early on a Thursday night but it soon filled with people, many of whom seemed to be regulars. Don't be put off by the size and appearance of the restaurant from the outside. I would rather eat well and receive good good service than apy over the top for fancy furnishings. The only negative I could see was the charge made for bread, as mentioned in the previous reviews. Though this did not spoil a very enjoyable meal.

review_preview: We were pleased with this small restaurant because of its original dishes, down to earth and attentive service and solid cost to quality ratio.  Goat's cheese with honey and basil vinagrette was excellent.  Codillo stuffed with tetilla cheese was another highlight.  One downer: they charge...
review_full: We were pleased with this small restaurant because of its original dishes, down to earth and attentive service and solid cost to quality ratio.  Goat's cheese with honey and basil vinagrette was excellent. Codillo stuffed with tetilla cheese was another highlight.  One downer: they charge you for the bread. It was about the only thing that felt non-gourmet but they charged as if it were. We visited for lunch on a Saturday and were one of three parties present. Very small place, clean and comfortable.

review_preview: I selected this restaurant as it was close to my hotel and I read the good reviews on Tripadvisor. I found it average, with some good dishes (entre of Guacamole with banana chips or Baked goat cheese) and some others really disappointing (Octopus in a...
review_full: I selected this restaurant as it was close to my hotel and I read the good reviews on Tripadvisor. I found it average, with some good dishes (entre of Guacamole with banana chips or Baked goat cheese) and some others really disappointing (Octopus in a creamy sauce and, I think was called Enchiladas). Desserts are good. If you're looking for more traditional Spanish cuisine don't go there, it's ok if you're just for a snack. friendly staff, but rather poor service. For what we have eaten (30 EUR each) it was also rather expensive.

review_full: This is one of the gems you're looking for in Madrid. Look beyond the entrance and grab one the tables beyond the bar. The service is warm & friendly and gives you the feeling that they want you to have a good experience. The food is innovative, modern Spanish at a high level. One of the staff members speaks English and will explain the entire menu. We let him do the recommendation and were not disappointed. Don't forget to try their desserts! PS: The place is fairly small so it may be wise to phone ahead.  C/Pelayo 8, Chueca

Very fun! We will be recommending this place to all friends and family on future visits to Madrid.

I opted for the bowl where you choose ingredients (up to 5) by yourself and a dressing too, all for €6,70. I also appreciated the tap water. Very worth the price!

review_preview: We stayed in Chueca for three nights in May and spent most of our time dining in the area.  By far, Gastromaquia was the best dining experience we had during our stay.  From the friendly warm service, Anderson took care of our every need, and...
review_full: We stayed in Chueca for three nights in May and spent most of our time dining in the area. By far, Gastromaquia was the best dining experience we had during our stay. From the friendly warm service, Anderson took care of our every need, and he even walked us to a local bar after dinner to ensure we knew where we were going. There were 4 in our group, and we ordered Tapas, including cheese & meat platter, sliders, spicy pappas, and ribs. All of the food was flavorful, the meat was juicy, and the simple clean ambiance made for a delicious experience.

title_review: The place to go for an excellent brunch!
review_preview: We visited this ‘little gem’ on our first visit to Madrid after reading really good reviews on TripAdvisor, and we’re so glad that we did. The food was delicious and very well presented. From the mini brunch menu, I chose a glass of cava (orange...
review_full: We visited this ‘little gem’ on our first visit to Madrid after reading really good reviews on TripAdvisor, and we’re so glad that we did. The food was delicious and very well presented. From the mini brunch menu, I chose a glass of cava (orange juice was another option), earl grey tea, and a bacon, lettuce and tomato wrap. My husband ordered 2 poached eggs on toast with salad, a glass of orange juice and english breakfast tea. The staff were very attentive, and on our way out, it was a real pleasure to meet the owner Emma who was so lovely. I would certainly recommend this venue, we will definitely return on our next trip to Madrid. Well done Emma and staff, we hope to see you again soon!

title_review: Great food for a phenomenal price
review_preview: I had a great meal in this restaurant. I started with the tuna loin accompanied by a salad that perfectly combined the sweetness of mango with a bit of heat, if anything the portion was a bit too big for one person but it was...
review_full: I had a great meal in this restaurant. I started with the tuna loin accompanied by a salad that perfectly combined the sweetness of mango with a bit of heat, if anything the portion was a bit too big for one person but it was so good I persevered through the whole dish. I then had the pan fried fish of the day with saffron risotto, this day it was a piece of brilliantly cooked salmon, still moist in the centre, with crispy skin. I didn't have any drinks with my meal so I was expecting the bill to be reasonable, but I was still shocked by how small the bill was. The restaurant is fairly simple, the service is pleasant and efficient, all round a really nice place.

review_preview: My wife and I visited this restaurant whilst in Madrid and were blown away. Some of the food was up there with the best we’ve ever had. Every dish was packed with flavour, and had a modern twist on Tapas. The Mussels in an Indian...
review_full: My wife and I visited this restaurant whilst in Madrid and were blown away. Some of the food was up there with the best we’ve ever had.  Every dish was packed with flavour, and had a modern twist on Tapas. The Mussels in an Indian spiced broth were incredible.  Potions were extremely generous, we just order several plates to share and didn’t go hungry. A Ribera wine to accompany meal was perfect and great value.  When the bill came, we thought we’d been undercharged. We hadn’t, it was just great value. If you are staying in Madrid, take a short walk out of the city centre, avoid the tourist trap restaurants and visit Gastromaquia

review_preview: Honestly, looking at the other reviews I feel bad for giving a 3/5. It could be a one-off experience, but not everyone can be satisfied. To put it briefly, the food was nice but the dishes we had were not particularly special. The best dish...
review_full: Honestly, looking at the other reviews I feel bad for giving a 3/5. It could be a one-off experience, but not everyone can be satisfied. To put it briefly, the food was nice but the dishes we had were not particularly special. The best dish was a starter, the goat cheese with pesto. The other dishes were ok, but not great. For example, the bbq ribs portion was massive, slattered in bbq sauce, and accompanied by plain fried potato balls with mayo. The dish would have benefitted from some variation. Another dish, the duck, suffered from the fact that the puree was tastier than the duck, which was slightly underdone in some parts. Finally, we ended up giving a tip (10%), but instead of being thanked the response was "ok". I'm sure this is just a one-off experience, but it did not fit the other reviews we had read. Overall the food was descent and the service was good, but the other reviews make it feel like we missed out.

review_preview: My wife and I visited Gastromaquia for lunch and tried the Bluefin Tuna, Grilled Goat Cheese, and Fried Eggs. The tuna was fresh and tender and topped with sweet mango, tomatoes, pomegranates, onions, airy rice noodles, and sriracha mayo. The goat cheese was creamy and...
review_full: My wife and I visited Gastromaquia for lunch and tried the Bluefin Tuna, Grilled Goat Cheese, and Fried Eggs. The tuna was fresh and tender and topped with sweet mango, tomatoes, pomegranates, onions, airy rice noodles, and sriracha mayo. The goat cheese was creamy and topped with honey and a basil pesto sauce. The salty and yolky fried eggs sat on a bed of savory potatoes and were topped with diced bacon and scallions. Overall, Gastromaquia is a solid spot for lunch.

review_full: Cool modern ambience; good service. Excellent tapas. We took sharing plates: aubergine (perhaps the least tasty), the spicy mussels; the mini burgers (delicious and succulent); and the ribs. title_review: Outstanding food, friendly service, reasonable prices
review_preview: We visited Gastromaquia for a light supper recently. We had the octopus with potato foam, "crunchy aubergines", and slow cooked ribs. Each dish was very well executed. We love octopus and this was the best we had on our stay in Madrid - perfectly seasoned...
review_full: We visited Gastromaquia for a light supper recently. We had the octopus with potato foam, "crunchy aubergines", and slow cooked ribs. Each dish was very well executed. We love octopus and this was the best we had on our stay in Madrid - perfectly seasoned and the potato foam was a nice upgrade on the traditional potato base. The ribs were meltingly tender and flavoursome, and the aubergines were delicious too. We had 2 glasses of Protos Roble (about €5 a glass, very cheap), and the lovely waiter left the bottle with us. Service throughout was very friendly, quick but not overly so. I would definitely return to Gastromaquia.

title_review: Tasty, inventive food and good service
review_preview: We went here during our stay in Madrid. A pleasant surprise was that the lady spoke good English so a noob in Spanish could actually say something meaningful. We had a shared tuna tataki, which was a really beautiful dish, and also inventive and tasty....
review_full: We went here during our stay in Madrid. A pleasant surprise was that the lady spoke good English so a noob in Spanish could actually say something meaningful. We had a shared tuna tataki, which was a really beautiful dish, and also inventive and tasty. This dish could have been served in an even fancier restaurant. Highly recommend you to try it. For our main dish we went with a safe option, the entrecot. The meat was great in medium, quite red but also very tasty. Also recommended. Everything went so smooth we ended up going here twice on the same trip. On our second visit we tried other dishes, they were good but not excellent. Hence the four stars for food, if we had only gone the once it would be 5* on food.

review_preview: Gastromaquia is aptly named. With early 8:30 reservations, for awhile we were the only customers in the restaurant. By 10:00 it was completely full, so make reservations as the Spanish eat late.All the tapas we ate were excellent. Highlights included Octopus with Potato Foam...
review_full: Gastromaquia is aptly named. With early 8:30 reservations, for awhile we were the only customers in the restaurant. By 10:00 it was completely full, so make reservations as the Spanish eat late. All the tapas we ate were excellent. Highlights included Octopus with Potato Foam and the Tikki Masala Mussels in an Indian-flavored broth. Our favorite was the caramelized Grilled Goat Cheese with honey vinaigrette and basil pesto. Dinner entrees were excellent. Find out what the fish of the day is being served. The food execution was nicely paced, wine constantly flowed, and our server was the best. A great Spanish foodie finale for our trip! Gastromaquia is my #1 choice when I return to Madrid. Chueca barrio has come a long way!

title_review: Superb, delicious, hidden gem in Chueca!
review_preview: We read reviews about this outstanding eatery, but didn’t know what to expect. Arrived a little late, but that didn’t matter to the staff at Gastromaquia! They quickly accommodated us! The wait staff was impeccable with taking and delivery our order. We loved our entrees...
review_full: We read reviews about this outstanding eatery, but didn’t know what to expect. Arrived a little late, but that didn’t matter to the staff at Gastromaquia! They quickly accommodated us! The wait staff was impeccable with taking and delivery our order. We loved our entrees so much we returned for a second visit! Our first visit we have the octopus in potato foam to start with the black risotto and squid and fish minueire. Our second visit included the surf & turf and duck entrees. All dishes were superbly prepared! The staff was so outstanding they offered us the mushroom croquet complimentary, during our second visit. We had the Albariño white wine both visits. Gastromquia is located in the heart of the Chueca district! We can’t wait to come back. This is a restaurant not to be missed!

review_preview: A wonderful find on Trip Advisor which has not let us down on our recent visit to Madrid. Booking is a must as this little place has a loyal following and a steady stream of "drop-ins". The menu is small, but carefully chosen dishes, made...
review_full: A wonderful find on Trip Advisor which has not let us down on our recent visit to Madrid. Booking is a must as this little place has a loyal following and a steady stream of "drop-ins".  The menu is small, but carefully chosen dishes, made with high quality ingredients and cooked with care shines through...... dont change a thing, its a masterpiece of less is more! We arrived early an were seated immediately and had a leisurely set menu brunch of three courses which set us up for a days sightseeing in the City. Its busy, buzzy atmosphere and compact size means there always sights, smells and stimulation. The queue for tables is often out the door and down the block.

review_preview: With all the choices in Madrid, it's hard to decide on what to eat.  My husband and I had the same argument -  and he tricked me into coming to Gastromaquia.  As our dishes started to arrive, I was pleasantly surprised by how good the...
review_full: With all the choices in Madrid, it's hard to decide on what to eat. My husband and I had the same argument - and he tricked me into coming to Gastromaquia. As our dishes started to arrive, I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was. The dishes came out at a good pace, and everything was well presented. We ordered the tuna tartare (which was my favorite dish), the fried egg with truffle (which my husband practically licked the plate clean afterwards), and the octopus with potato foam. We 'finished" the meal off with the black rice, which was nice and full of flavor. All in all, it was a solid meal that didn't cost us an arm and a leg. Great service - menu available in English, and the servers speak fluent English. Free wifi available. Reservations recommended.

review_preview: I've been quite disappointed with food in Madrid before I checked out this place. The owner is very friendly, can talk for hours and speak good English. The food is very good with some of the dishes being excellent. Guacamole was delicious. Foie Gras in...
review_full: I've been quite disappointed with food in Madrid before I checked out this place. The owner is very friendly, can talk for hours and speak good English. The food is very good with some of the dishes being excellent. Guacamole was delicious. Foie Gras in bread crumbs, hmm nothing I would expect, but it wasn't bad. Octopus was tender and tasty but heavily soaked in cream. Now, here comes the most important and valuable information non of other trip-advisors bothered to mention. The place is VERY casual and EXTREMELY small. Think of a fast-food joint kind of environment in a closet kind of space. It is very bright and claustrophobic, so if you want to have a romantic dinner or have more than 1 friend to dine with, stay away from this place, you'll be stepped on and hear every gossip in the house.

review_preview: I have to join in with most people who have reviewed Gastromaquia and write that this is an excellent place to eat in Madrid. We ate there, I believe, Easter Saturday night 2012.  We found the place through Tripadvisor   The restaurant is small, so I...
review_full: I have to join in with most people who have reviewed Gastromaquia and write that this is an excellent place to eat in Madrid. We ate there, I believe, Easter Saturday night 2012. We found the place through Tripadvisor The restaurant is small, so I would reserve. Plates on the shortish menu are to share. What was most striking about the food were the unusual preperations of wonderful things that we all have been eating for years but here they are done differently AND deliciously. We had tiny boiled potatoes that were bathed in wonderful red sauce from the Canary Islands. Then the most delcious curried mussels. The mussels wonderfully fresh, the curry gravey divine. We also had grilled asparagus with a light cheese topping of some sort that was perfect and great desserts. Along with a bottle of wine, the bill for two was about 63 euros. My companion couldn't believe the bill and said "Wow! Our best meal, but the cheapest price!" The restaurant was crowded and there was a small bar in the front. Everyone was talking, laughing and enjoying themselves greatly. Serrvers were knowledgeable and friendly. Make sure you try this place.

title_review: Read this after you have read two other reviews at your discretion
review_preview: Here is the thing. Madrid is a wonderful, exciting, incredible city but the food can get very repetitive. Fast. How many times can you eat oily mediocre ham and heavy croquetas with lukewarm tortilla? I love Madrid, and have lived here but I understand that...
review_full: Here is the thing. Madrid is a wonderful, exciting, incredible city but the food can get very repetitive. Fast. How many times can you eat oily mediocre ham and heavy croquetas with lukewarm tortilla? I love Madrid, and have lived here but I understand that sometimes that craving for something different, something a little fresher is too hard to ignore. So. La Taberna is very good. But to me, it was my personal standard of good. Yes, the ingredients were fresh, a little different and a little lighter than what I had been eating all week. The Guacamole was....guac. What can I say? It was as good as any. And the pork skewar was very tender and nice, but the same as you could get for a dollar from a vendor in a street cart in New York. The rabbit was wonderfully tender but very salty and overpowered the braising liquid. I know I sound pretentious, its just that I really enjoy great food which shouldn´t be that hard to find and this was just that. Good simple food, just not knock your socks off gourmet extravaganza.

title_review: Just what you always hope you'll find in a new town - fun and good.
review_preview: The whole Chueca neighborhood is great. It was right under our noses the whole time - We took a cab to Taberna Gastromaquia and felt at home the minute we walked in. (dopey mistake to take a cab when it was a 10 minute walk...
review_full: The whole Chueca neighborhood is great. It was right under our noses the whole time - We took a cab to Taberna Gastromaquia and felt at home the minute we walked in. (dopey mistake to take a cab when it was a 10 minute walk plus the guy gave us the 10 Euro tour getting there, but I suppose we deserved it.) Food involves modern takes on Spanish classics. Wine was splendid and the only slight disappointment was a big dish of octopus in cheese sauce which was almost inedibly rich. Hugo (who's the chef and a terrific host as you can tell by the reviews)conferred with us about everything, and was a delight. He was sad that we didn't care that much for the octopus but everything else was lovely. Dessert was a sorbet which was some of the best I have ever had, and my friend had a frappe of some sort that we both fought over to scrape the last bite. Just a totally fun evening in a place that's doing well because of Trip Advisor, but not taking any of it for granted. Excellent (perfect) English spoken here too by the way.

The octopus was wonderul, the ribs to die for. In fact every dish we had was superb and well presented. The chef recommended two sorbet-type deserts he lovingly described as how his grandmother prepared sangria in his childhood...they were excellent. The decor is more diner than gourmet, so come here to savour the great food and warm welcome. It is very small and the definition of "family" run so I can imagine that service might be a bit harried at peak times. get here soon, since I believe it will be overrun or the whole operation "upgraded" in the not too distant future.

title_review: Over Priced, Under Cooked and Misleading
review_preview: We dined at this cafe for brunch - we were given the set menu which is very expensive 12€ for a small coffee, warm orange juice and small eggs benedict. The eggs were very undercooked and the whole dish was soggy. After the meal we...
review_full: We dined at this cafe for brunch - we were given the set menu which is very expensive 12€ for a small coffee, warm orange juice and small eggs benedict.  The eggs were very undercooked and the whole dish was soggy. After the meal we saw a menu behind us that offered much cheaper options such as avocado on toast - €3 and we were never told about this.  There’s far cheaper places to brunch in Madrid and I really would not recommend the Brunch Club.

title_review: Lucky to stumble upon this place
review_preview: We had been shopping and sightseeing nearby and did not have cell service at the time so we stumbled in to Gastromaquia without checking reviews and preplanning. We were very happy to have discovered it! We were very early by Spanish scheduling (but late by...
review_full: We had been shopping and sightseeing nearby and did not have cell service at the time so we stumbled in to Gastromaquia without checking reviews and preplanning. We were very happy to have discovered it! We were very early by Spanish scheduling (but late by American stomachs!) and the place was pretty empty. Usually this gives me a nervous feeling that perhaps it's empty for a reason. Nope, it was only empty because of the time of day. The paella we ordered we devoured. It was mostly gone before either one of us thought to take a photo. Our waitress was very kind, checked in on us regularly, and let us know when the food was getting close as they prepare it only upon order and not in advance, as good paella must be done. This was great comfort food, in a cool and quiet setting, with excellent service and not unreasonably expensive. Check, check, check, and check! What more can you ask for? We left full and wishing we had found this restaurant on our first day instead of our last.
